entry.title: Verifying ISP performance with Raspberry Pi and pandas
entry.summary: This story begins, as do so many, with a user complaint about sluggish application response time.
entry.content:
This story begins, as do so many, with a user complaint about sluggish application response.

My wife has the opportunity to work from home from time to time, which makes the reliability and performance of our home Internet service more important than it would be if it was only for recreational use. When she experienced several instances of sluggish application responsiveness one week, it seemed like a good time to collect some data and verfiy the ISP performance.

As an added bonus, this also gave me a chance to bring the Python data analysis tools to bear on a focused question for which I have a personal connection to the data.

The question is:¶

Is my ISP reliable and performing to the advertised service level?¶

Setup¶

As a first cut at checking performance, I decided to run speedtest measurements every 10 minutes for two weeks. After that I made measurements at longer intervals for another 12 weeks.

This isn’t a practical long term approach for multiple reasons. Running speedtest consumes network capacity that’s no longer available to other, more useful, applications. Even more importantly, my service has a “Monthly Data Allowance,” and running speedtest too often will overrun the data cap, leading to an overage charge — Terrible, Horrible, No Good, Very Bad.

Preliminaries¶

To measure internet throughput, I connected a Raspberry Pi 3 Model B with an ethernet cable directly to a port on the broadband modem (Arris Cable Modem model DG2470A) and added a cron job to run a script and record the results automatically at specific predetermined intervals.

Since the onboard LAN port port on the Raspberry Pi is only 10/100 Mbps, I needed to add a USB GE LAN adapter, as suggested by Jeff Geerling in this blog post: Getting Gigabit Networking on a Raspberry Pi 2, 3 and B+

I chose the TRENDnet USB 3.0 to Gigabit Ethernet Network Adapter, TU3-ETG.

The advertised service level from the ISP is:¶

  • 200 Mbps Download
  • 15 Mbps Upload
  • 1 TB Monthly Data Allowance

The “1 TB Monthly Data Allowance” effectively means that the 200 Mbps download is a maximum burst rate. If a 200 Mbps download could be sustained, the full monthly data allowance would be consumed in a little more than 11 hours.

Transferring 1 TB at 200 Mbps takes:¶

$$\left( {10^{12}\,B} \right) \left( \frac{8\,b}{B} \right) \left(\frac {1\,s} {200×10^6\,b} \right) \left( \frac{1\,hr}{3600\,s} \right) = 11.1\, hr$$

The maximmum sustained rate wthout exceeding the data cap would be 3 - 3.3 Mb/s (depending on what the ISP means by “1 TB”).

Converting 1 TB/Month to Mbits/second (Mbps):¶

$$\left( \frac{10^{12}\,B}{mo} \right) \left( \frac{12\,mo}{365\,day} \right) \left( \frac{1\,day}{24\,hr} \right) \left( \frac{1\,hr}{3600\,s} \right) \left( \frac{8\,b}{B} \right) \left( \frac{ 1\,Mb}{10^6\,b} \right)= 3.04\,Mbps$$

$$\left( \frac{2^{40}\,B}{mo} \right) \left( \frac{12\,mo}{365\,day} \right) \left( \frac{1\,day}{24\,hr} \right) \left( \frac{1\,hr}{3600\,s} \right) \left( \frac{8\,b}{B} \right) \left( \frac{ 1\,Mb}{10^6\,b} \right)= 3.35\,Mbps$$

What that really means is…¶

Based on this information, the best way to think of the service agreement is as:

  • 3 Mbps Sustained Data Rate
  • 200 Mbps Maximum Burst Rate

There’s no indication from the ISP regarding what the Maximum Burst Size might be.

1. Install speedtest.cli¶

Most people check their home Internet performance by using the speedtest website, and in fact my ISP recommends that as well.

Fortunately there’s a CLI version, speedtest-cli, written by Matt Martz which allows testing to be scripted and automated.

Installation is simple:

sudo apt-get install python-pip
sudo pip install speedtest-cli

2. Bash Script¶

Here’s a simple bash script to run speedtest and append the results to a file:

#!/bin/sh
TMPFILE=`mktemp -t speedtest.XXXXXX`
CSVFILE=/var/local/speedtest.csv
DATE=$(date)

/usr/local/bin/speedtest-cli --simple > $TMPFILE
MSG=`cat $TMPFILE | perl -pe 's/^(.*): (.*) (.*?)(\/s)?\n/$2,/m' | cut -d',' -f 1-3`
printf "${DATE},$MSG\n" >> $CSVFILE
rm -f $TMPFILE

This script can be scheduled to run automatically, e.g. every 10 minutes, by adding a crontab entry that looks like this:

# execute every 10 minutes
*/10 * * * * /home/pi/bin/speedtest2log.sh

Note that user pi needs to have read/write permissions to the output file(s) (/var/local/speedtest.csv) for this to work.

Results and Analysis¶

Here’s some typical output from running the script:

In [1]:
!head speedtest.csv

Datetime,Ping_ms,Download_Mbps,Upload_Mbps
Sun Jun 18 19:33:44 EDT 2017,24.26,197.99,15.94
Sun Jun 18 20:45:42 EDT 2017,24.099,189.31,16.47
Sun Jun 18 21:19:48 EDT 2017,24.066,198.83,16.36
Sun Jun 18 22:00:25 EDT 2017,20.964,200.19,17.36
Sun Jun 18 22:11:17 EDT 2017,23.6,199.14,16.09
Sun Jun 18 22:15:01 EDT 2017,21.426,201.61,16.53
Sun Jun 18 22:30:01 EDT 2017,25.715,175.77,15.84
Sun Jun 18 22:40:01 EDT 2017,21.751,146.37,16.60
Sun Jun 18 22:50:01 EDT 2017,22.418,200.60,16.18

The Python Pandas Data Analysis Library is a great tool for analyzing data like this. Here I’m using it within a Jupyter notebook.

In [2]:
import sys                             # system module
import datetime as dt                  # date and time module
import pandas as pd                    # data package
import numpy as np

import matplotlib as mpl               # graphics package
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt        # pyplot module
import seaborn

%matplotlib inline
plt.style.use('seaborn-paper')
In [3]:
# show versions (probably overkill, but why not?)
#
print('Python version:', sys.version)
print('Pandas version: ', pd.__version__)
print('Matplotlib version: ', mpl.__version__)

Python version: 3.5.2 |Anaconda custom (64-bit)| (default, Jul  2 2016, 17:53:06) 
[GCC 4.4.7 20120313 (Red Hat 4.4.7-1)]
Pandas version:  0.20.1
Matplotlib version:  2.0.2
In [4]:
# Read the CSV data file as a dataframe
csvfile = 'speedtest.csv'
df = pd.read_csv(csvfile)
df = df.rename(columns={'Download_Mbps': 'Download',
                        'Upload_Mbps': 'Upload',
                        'Ping_ms': 'Ping'
                       })
df.info()


RangeIndex: 2241 entries, 0 to 2240
Data columns (total 4 columns):
Datetime    2241 non-null object
Ping        2241 non-null float64
Download    2241 non-null float64
Upload      2241 non-null float64
dtypes: float64(3), object(1)
memory usage: 70.1+ KB

Summary statistics:¶

In [5]:
# Using default percentiles
df.describe()
Out[5]:
Ping Download Upload
count 2241.000000 2241.000000 2241.000000
mean 23.628222 183.575756 16.652718
std 2.777095 23.106646 0.538496
min 18.972000 43.230000 7.000000
25% 21.848000 172.450000 16.440000
50% 22.988000 192.370000 16.560000
75% 24.528000 200.590000 16.760000
max 47.549000 209.630000 19.030000
In [6]:
# Using custom percentiles
df.describe(percentiles=[0.05, 0.10, 0.5, 0.6, 0.70, 0.8, 0.9])
Out[6]:
Ping Download Upload
count 2241.000000 2241.000000 2241.000000
mean 23.628222 183.575756 16.652718
std 2.777095 23.106646 0.538496
min 18.972000 43.230000 7.000000
5% 20.658000 136.060000 16.310000
10% 21.056000 148.900000 16.360000
50% 22.988000 192.370000 16.560000
60% 23.527000 198.260000 16.620000
70% 24.125000 200.000000 16.700000
80% 25.137000 201.290000 16.860000
90% 27.078000 203.060000 17.240000
max 47.549000 209.630000 19.030000

Download Performace¶

  • Mean Download rate is 183 Mbps
  • Median Download rate is 192 Mbps
  • 70% of download measurements are equal or less than the advertised peak rate (200 Mbps)
  • 5% of download measurements are less than 136 Mbps

Upload Performance¶

  • Mean Upload rate is 16.6 Mbps

Fewer than 1% of Download measurements are below 100 Mb/s¶

In [7]:
df[df['Download'] < 100].count() / df['Download'].count()
Out[7]:
Datetime    0.004462
Ping        0.004462
Download    0.004462
Upload      0.004462
dtype: float64

Upload performance is even better, relative to the advertised rate (15 Mb/s)¶

Fewer than 1% of upload measurements are below 15 Mb/s

In [8]:
df[df['Upload'] < 15].count() / df['Upload'].count()
Out[8]:
Datetime    0.005355
Ping        0.005355
Download    0.005355
Upload      0.005355
dtype: float64

Add a datetime column¶

The original Datetime column was interpreted by pandas as a string type object. Let’s add a new column of type datetime to facilitate analyzing as a timeseries.

In [9]:
df2 = df.rename(columns={'Datetime': 'Date'})
df2['datetime'] = pd.to_datetime(df2['Date'])
df2['HourOfDay'] = df2['datetime'].dt.hour

# set index to the `datetime` field
df3 = df2.set_index('datetime')
df3['Datetime'] = df3.index

Plotting the data¶

Plotting the results provides a visual sense of the data.

Scatter Plot¶

In [10]:
# specify plot size (width, height) in inches, and resolution (DPI)
plt.figure(figsize=(8,4), dpi=100)
ax = plt.axes()
ax.plot(df3['Datetime'], df3['Download'], '.', color='black')
ax.plot(df3['Datetime'], df3['Upload'], '.', color='red')
ax.set(xlabel='Datetime', ylabel='Mbps', title='Througput (as reported by speedtest)')
ax.legend(loc='best')
Out[10]:

Histogram¶

In [11]:
# First create a grid of plots
# ax will be an array of two Axes objects
fig, ax = plt.subplots(2, figsize=(8,6), dpi=100)

# Call hist() method on the appropriate axis object
ax[0].hist(df3['Download'], bins=20, normed=True)
ax[0].set_ylabel('Download')

ax[1].hist(df3['Upload'], bins=20, normed=True, color='green')
ax[1].set_ylabel('Upload')
ax[1].set_xlabel('Mbps')
Out[11]:

Cumulative Distribution¶

Another interesting thing to see is a cumulative distribution function. This shows the probability of finding a number in a bin or any lower bin. This is as simple as adding a single flag to the hist() call.

In [12]:
# Download 
plt.figure(figsize=(8,4), dpi=100)
ax = plt.axes()
ax.hist(df3['Download'], bins=20, normed=True, cumulative=True)
ax.set(xlabel='Mbps', title='Download Throughput')
Out[12]:
[,
 ]
In [13]:
# Upload
plt.figure(figsize=(8,4), dpi=100)
ax = plt.axes()
ax.hist(df3['Upload'], bins=20, normed=True, cumulative=True, color='green')
ax.set(xlabel='Mbps', title='Upload Throughput')
Out[13]:
[,
 ]

Checking for patterns of intraday variation¶

Group observations by Hour-of-Day to look for variations in performance over the course of the day.

In [14]:
x = df3.pivot(index='Datetime', columns='HourOfDay', values='Download')
plt.figure(figsize=(8,3), dpi=100)
x.boxplot()
Out[14]:

There are no obvious patterns shown in the hourly box plot.

Conclusion¶

Recalling the measured performance summary statistics for convenience:

In [15]:
df.describe()
Out[15]:
Ping Download Upload
count 2241.000000 2241.000000 2241.000000
mean 23.628222 183.575756 16.652718
std 2.777095 23.106646 0.538496
min 18.972000 43.230000 7.000000
25% 21.848000 172.450000 16.440000
50% 22.988000 192.370000 16.560000
75% 24.528000 200.590000 16.760000
max 47.549000 209.630000 19.030000

Answering the original question¶

Upload performance is remarkably good.¶

This is mainly relevant when doing off-site backups or sending large files.

Download performance is pretty respectable, too.¶

Half of all Downloads measured 192 Mbps or better; 40% measured 198 Mbps or better. Only 10 of over 2000 Download measurements (0.4%) are below 100 Mbps.

Given that the effective offered Download performance is 200 Mbps Peak, 3 Mbps Sustained, a Mean Download rate of 183 Mbps and Minimum of 43 Mbps is really quite respectable. This may not be acceptable for a Business Class customer, but for home/home-office use, the results show consistently good performance.

These results indicates to me that whatever issues were affecting my wife’s work are more likely to be found by looking somewhere else, perhaps at the VPN, or the host PC applications.

Latency to the speedtest server looks reasonable, too, though speedtest absolutely isn’t the best way to measure latency.

Next steps¶

Working on this performance question got me thinking about practical approaches for continuous monitoring of networks and servers. I’ve been working with several tools and approaches which I plan to discuss in another post.
